FRIDAY, AUG. 14, 1885.

REFERENCE.

Present indications point to a rather lively competition for the forthcoming election for the North West Council, and we must confess to a feeling of surprise that this should be the case. We believe, in our opinion there can be found more to object to than to count in the position. In the first place while the work which has to be done by the Council is of the most necessary in itself just alike as well be undertaken without the presence of the electoral element at all, nor is any sane man deceived into the opinion that in going to the Council they are not sent a member that is in any way enjoying representative government. While the whole body of the Council has no power to initiate anything of considerable benefit to the people it is no less necessary to make sure that the bulk of the constituency recognize this fact, and it is very questionable as to whether any man having political aspirations will not seriously damage his eventual prospects by occupying a seat at the Council board-to-day. Any good that a member is likely to do his district under present circumstances is apt to be far proportional to the amount of influence he may be able to bring to bear personally upon the Government, and as that sort of influence entails frequent visits to Ottawa, it may be furthermore laid down that the amount of benefit he can hope to confer upon his constituents will bear a distinct relation to the length of his purse. It seems, however, that the experience of those gentlemen who have been members and have been out of pocket by the occupation of this position is not such as to prompt them to desire to resume it, nor can it be denied that it has a very strong tendency to be a very thankless task. Nevertheless, so far as what has been done for the district by the retiring members is such as to prevent its being generally recognized, and it is a poor lookout for the next candidate to find Mr. Macdonald granting his objections to assuming such a task a commonplace thing, and the fact of finding the utmost unwillingness in him to greater expense than he feels justified in incurring. Under these circumstances it becomes a matter of vital necessity that the councils of the district be consulted with all possible dispatch, and then there really is no just reason why any expense should be incurred. What we wish to draw the attention of the people to is the fact that if they vote to put a good man to represent them and aid us as possible to advocate their interests, it is their business to put him there; for a candidate must feel that he is open to the suspicion that he is interested in the interest involved if he can be expected to spend time and money and beg votes as a favor in order to secure the position. Of the number of names mentioned in connection with the various seats there are several men quite equal to undertaking all the legitimate duties attaching to the position, but it is high time that steps were taken to reduce that number to such a point that every probability that unless there is every possibility to concentrate their energies, the upshot of the business will be that some one of those in every way the least desirable may find himself elected. We protest that no one of the gentlemen who are likely to do us credit will accept a nomination without knowing pretty exactly the amount of support he can depend upon, nor is there any reason why such information should not be forthcoming with tolerable accuracy when required.

The recently appointed Governor of the Hudson Bay Company, who has been making a tour of inspection through the Territory, gave a banquet on Saturday night to an assemblage of about forty-five, composed of members of the district and a number of others who happen to be here on Government business of various sorts. This entertainment turned out a complete success, and Mr. H. B. Co. Wingfield made a most happy impression upon those who had the honor of making his acquaintance for the first time. An interesting feature of the occasion was the appearance of Messrs. Munro and Quinn, the Government Commissioners who have come to inquire into the claims of those who have suffered loss in consequence of the late rebellion. We regretted not having known of this before making some remarks which appear in our last issue. However, we have much pleasure in using our opportunity to express the hope of Commissioners made by the Government is certain to insure a completely satisfactory settlement of the claims in question. Mr. Munro has been a lawyer by trade, and the sending of a man of that stamp is evidence of the desire of the Government to do what is fair in the matter. Mr. Munro has had a great deal of experience of this sort of work, and assures us that he will approach the matter in a liberal spirit, and that the Government wishes to settle up the losses of the people at once, intending to let the H. B. Co. and others who can better afford to do so wait until such people have been paid. Mr. Quinn represents Lower Canada upon this Commission, and a very few words with him impresses one with the idea that his ability for the work is such that in which he is engaged alone it has never been desired. We were delighted with the way in which he explained the public sentiment of Quebec with regard to the unfortunate rebellion.

We learn from reliable sources that the distress at Dartmouth has been considerably exaggerated when reported, and that all cases of real necessity have been attended to by direction of the Government. If we have not been giving the Government credit for such discretion as it has already been making it is only because we have been kept in the dark with regard to their proceedings.

WHAT WAS IT?

To the Editor of The Times,

Sir,—Last Friday night about eleven o'clock there was seen a bright light rising up from the summit of the hill. You will remember there was a very bright moon—but from the flight of the lamp on its arriving we judge it was hill, could be seen to be traversing the summit of the hill, which step was broken at intervals by a sudden halt. Some hours after this, the light was seen again, and was once again visible on the top of the hill. Now what could this mean? Was there anyone there that night, and if so, were his friends still residing along in search of him? Or, were these two, who visited the scene of the photograph taken lately, and on seeing the "just like life," were so pleased, that the town became too small to hold them? PATROL.

**THE CAPITAL.**

*Ottawa, Aug. 2.* There is no truth in the rumor that Gen. Middleton has recommended the presentation of a medal to the North-West Mounted Police who took part in the recent engagements.

At an interview today the Minister of Agriculture said that the recommenda-
tion of the committee appointed by the Cana-
dian Government in aid of the Arts and
agricultural Associations, that it was not
worth while to expend more than $2,000 of the money in making a Mani-
toba and Maritime Provinces display at
the coming Exhibition in London.

The minister promised orders any volun-

called out for special drill this year,

**CHICAGO.**

*Chicago, Aug. 2.* Commencing short-
ly after daylight this morning, the fire
began below the street level.

Early in the day the rain poured down in tor-
rents, and hardly shocked up to what
could be called ordinary weather late in the
afternoon.

At 10 p.m. the fire became heavier, filling the people with
apprehensions of a deluge, and the indi-
cations were that the flames would rage all night.

Twelve hours from the com-
mencement of the alarm, the signal ser-
vice officer reported twenty inches.

At this hour the amount must
be quite six inches.

The damage to the
property and lives of the inhab-
itants is very great.

Since early this evening the department of police
has been engaged in the most strenuous attempt
of reports of damage of this nature.

At six o'clock the elevators in the new
opera house were set on fire.

Clark and Washington streets began to burn.

The water in the basement had
got out the fire under the boilers.

There are several complaints from many sources.

**THE MEMORIAL.**

At a meeting of the residents of Prince
Albert and the surrounding districts, to
take steps towards erecting a suitable
memorial to the brave soldiers and
men who fell fighting in honor of their
Queen and country, Mr. T. N. Camp-
bell was called to the chair, with Mr. S.
B. Spratt as secretary.

Moved by Col. Spratt and seconded by
Gen. Brown that in view of the sad and
terrible loss which has been incurred in
the death of nine of our brave citizen
soldiers, and three of the equally brave
members of the volunteer force, stationed
at Bear Lake, we do hereby express
our heartfelt appreciation of their ser-
vices and regret for their loss by an
appropriation of suitable amounts which
will stand forth in years to come as a memo-
rial of their worth to generations here-
after.

Resolved that a committee be appointed
with full powers to collect funds for
such purpose.

Moved by Mr. M. McWillie-
son seconded by Mr. Macdonald, that
the committee, after having collected the
necessary funds, do call a meeting of the
committee and decide upon the site and
design of the monument.

Moved by Mr. T. Agnew and seconded
by Mr. J. Murray that the monument
be open for two months, and that
in the meantime a suitable fence be
erected around the grounds St. Mary's
churchyard, where the Monument will be
erected to be admired by the Monctonians
and to be asked to remove the bodies of
the three Mounties. Polkton buried at
Cypress Point, together with those of
those of the volunteers.

It was unanimously resolved that the
committee report in the subdivision of
Thursday evening and make all the ne-
cessary arrangements for a general can-
vas of the country.

**A TORONTO FIRE.**

*Toronto, Aug. 1.* One of the most
destructive fires that has ever taken
place in Toronto commenced about 12.30
this morning in the large brick building
occupied by the English Sugar Refining
Company, the English Sugar Company
being the largest fire in the city.

The fire spread to the lumber yards
and warehouses on Yonge street and
all the intervening buildings and
warehouses have been burned to the ground.

The fire brigade are hard at work
putting out the fire and the firemen
are working day and night.

Public notice is hereby given that pro-

This land is under and by virtue of the

Saskatchewan Review.

E. DEWNEY,
Lt. Governor of the North West Terri-

THE REBELLION.

Contrary to expectations (see last No.), by the end of March there were very few of the loyalist settlers who had not found their way into the town; although some of the people of St. Catharines and the Portage district had been able to find shelter in the woods or in the river for some time longer. On the two last days of March and the early days of April there was no doubt but that the call of the rifle companies was answered in and formed into separate companies, the intention being to supply the place of the regulars, who had deserted. In order to do this the members of these companies were stationed not at angles armed with all the arms that could be spared, but to be ready to defend the town from the expected attack. The number of companies congregated in and about the town for protection became so large that the police and the citizens became convinced of the intention of the enemy to make an attempt to enter the town. It would have been easy to maintain the strength of the garrison at night, but the enemy had greatly increased the strength of the force which was to be used against them.

GREAT CANADA

We take the following from the Senate Debates, Hon. Dr. SCHULZELL—Besides, to consider whether the Government intends that greater Canada, comprising the two Provinces of Ontario and Quebec, together with the Lakes of the Woods and the Pacific Ocean, which contain our greatest natural resources, shall be represented in the Imperial Parliament by a single member, or whether it will be represented by two members, one for each Province.

The question is one of great importance, and I trust that the House will give it its attention.
